Award.AwardTitle: Assembly Of Near-IR Fluorescent Nanostructures With Emergent Properties
Award.AbstractNarration: With this award from the Organic and Macromolecular Chemistry Program, Prof. Bradley Smith plans to build on his recent discovery of squaraine-rotaxanes as very bright and extremely stable fluorescent near-infrared (NIR) dyes. Next-generation self-assembly methods will be developed to produce squaraine-macrocycle inclusion complexes in quantitative yields. The methods will be employed to construct elaborate NIR fluorescent nanostructures that have emergent properties. That is, the photophysical properties, chemical stabilities, and molecular recognition properties of the assembled nanostructures are superior to the individual building blocks. An attractive feature of this self-assembly strategy is its generality, which means that the building blocks (macrocycles and squaraine dyes) can be combined with almost any type of targeting ligand to rapidly produce fluorescent imaging probes that will have broad impact in materials science, biomedical science and nanotechnology. They will enable scientists to conduct photonic experiments that were previously impossible. One practical aim of the project is to utilize squaraine-rotaxanes as core scaffolds to construct NIR fluorescent dendrimers, which will have many applications, especially in biomedical imaging and diagnostic processes that employ Fluorescence Resonance Energy Transfer (FRET). A specific goal is to provide novel fluorescent reagents that enable new approaches to studying the complex process of gene delivery into cells using cationic dendrimers as transfection agents. Another practical aim is to produce NIR fluorescent imaging probes that can image many types of cancer cells; thus, they will aid studies of tumor biology, allow cancer detection in small animal models, and perhaps eventually facilitate fluorescence guided cancer surgery. The core training of research students will be in supramolecular photochemistry, but the applied aspects of the projects will teach them how to translate their discoveries into practical outcomes. The final practical aim of the proposal is to upgrade "Organic Structure Elucidation", a free internet workbook that already serves several thousands of chemistry students around the world, many of them in poorly equipped schools or under-developed countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work was conducted in the laboratory of Professor Bradley Smith in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at The University of Notre Dame, IN, with financial support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program of the National Science Foundation. A three year grant with one year no-cost extension supported postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students to develop new methods of making squaraine rotaxanes as some of the world’s brightest and most stable fluorescent dyes for many types of applications in modern society. With further development, squaraine rotaxanes will become superior replacements for the currently used cyanine dyes, especially in frontier technologies such as materials science, biomedical science and nanotechnology. The superior stabilities of squaraine-rotaxanes will enable imaging scientists to conduct experiments that were previously considered to be impossible. Major outcomes of the work include: (1) Development of new microwave-assisted synthesis methods that rapidly produce fluorescent squaraine rotaxane dyes in high yield. (2) Development of a fluorescent squaraine rotaxane system with ability to detect chloride ions using dip-stick technology. (3) Discovery of a new family of self-illuminating molecules that act as tiny flashlights. That is, they can be stored in a kitchen freezer and then made to glow by simply warming to body temperature. (4) Student training in advanced synthetic chemistry, photochemistry, photophysical measurements, chemical structure elucidation, and multimedia presentation of results. (5) Upgrade of the free internet workbook called Organic Structure Elucidation. The upgrade includes a new teaching feature called Dr Structure that provides strategic on-line assistance to student users.
